results.statement: The Role of Urinary Catheters. For decades, urinary catheters facilitate bladder drainage and enable precise urine output monitoring in acutely ill or post-operative patients.
results.matched_evidence:
- 1. Feneley 2015.pdf: The eponymous indwelling balloon-retained catheter (Figure 4) now in worldwide use was conceived by the American urologist Frederic Foley nearly 80 years ago to provide continuous urinary drainage and to control bleeding while haemostasis occurs, following transurethral prostatectomy [14].|The principal reasons for indwelling catheterization are as follows: (g) to obtain accurate measurements of urinary output in critically ill or post-operative patients;
- 2. Bladder Catheterization - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf.pdf: Bladder catheterization is performed perioperatively in most abdominopelvic surgeries, such as urological and gynecological procedures.|In cases of surgery on structures adjacent to the genitourinary tract, sheath catheters are recommended.[1] Bladder catheterization is also useful in surgical patients who require strict intraoperative urine output.
results.page_location: Page 4, column 1 and 2 | Page 2, under the 'Perioperative' section

results.statement: The Role of Urinary Catheters. Generally, about 25% of hospitalized individuals receive an indwelling urinary catheter.
results.reference: Amit R. Porwal, U.T. Mane, Amit C. Botre, Rahul S. Patil and A.T. Pardesi. Urinary Tract Infection in Indoor Patients with Indwelling Foley’s Catheterisation.4. Vallabha T, Ammanna H, Sindgikar V, Kullolli G, Saha A. Non-randomized Clinical Trial of In-house Silver-Coated Foley’s Catheter Reduces Urinary Tract Infections—a Low-Cost Innovation. Indian Journal of Surgery. 2021;84(4):818-823.
results.matched_evidence: - 3. Amit R, 2016.pdf: The 25% of hospitalized patients undergo urinary catheterisation and the incidence of infection is approximately 5-7% for each day of catheterisation.

results.statement: The Role of Urinary Catheters. With extensive use of urethral catheterization, related complications, and morbidity have increased too.
results.matched_evidence: - 4. Vallabha, 2021.pdf: With extensive use of bladder catheterization, related complications and morbidity have increased too.

results.statement: Burden of CAUTI. In India, CAUTI rate is 9.4 per 1000 catheter-days 14.7%5 with an overall prevalence of
results.reference: Sharma RK, Parihar SS, Kinimi SV, Choudhary S. An Observational Study from Northern India to Evaluate Catheter-associated Urinary Tract Infection in Medical Intensive Care Unit at a Tertiary Care Centre. Indian Journal of Critical Care Medicine. 2023;27(9):642-646.
results.matched_evidence: - 5. Sharma RK 2023.pdf: In this study, the CAUTI rate was 9.4 per 1000 urinary catheter days, while the overall magnitude was 14.67%.

results.statement: Burden of CAUTI. Each additional day of catheterization increases bacteriuria risk by 3-7%
results.reference: Sharma RK, Parihar SS, Kinimi SV, Choudhary S. An Observational Study from Northern India to Evaluate Catheter-associated Urinary Tract Infection in Medical Intensive Care Unit at a Tertiary Care Centre. Indian Journal of Critical Care Medicine. 2023;27(9):642-646.
results.matched_evidence: - 5. Sharma RK 2023.pdf: The duration of catheterization is the most important factor in the development of bacteriuria, as its daily usage increases the risk of infection by 3-7%.

results.statement: Impact of CAUTI. CAUTI increases the morbidity and mortality by 2.8-fold and length of hospitalization by 1-3 days. – CDC
results.reference: Soundaram GV, Sundaramurthy R, Jeyashree K, Ganesan V, Arunagiri R, Charles J. Impact of Care Bundle Implementation on Incidence of Catheter-associated Urinary Tract Infection: A Comparative Study in the Intensive Care Units of a Tertiary Care Teaching Hospital in South India. Indian Journal of Critical Care Medicine : Peer-reviewed, Official Publication of Indian Society of Critical Care Medicine. 2020;24(7):544-550.
results.matched_evidence:
- 6. Soundaram, 2020.pdf: According to the Centers
for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), CAUTI increases the
morbidity and mortality by 2.8-fold and length of hospitalization
by 1-3 days.

results.statement: Impact of CAUTI. Extends length of stay by 12.1 days outside of the ICU and 14.9 days inside the ICU
results.reference: Yu KC, Jung M, Ai C. Characteristics, costs, and outcomes associated with central-line–associated bloodstream infection and hospital-onset bacteremia and fungemia in US hospitals. Infection Control & Hospital Epidemiology. 2023;44(12):1920-1926.
results.matched_evidence: - 7. Yu, 2023.pdf: In adjusted regression analyses, CLABSI and non-CLABSI HОВ cases were associated with significantly longer hospital stays compared with the control cohort.|The mean differences were 15.6 and 12.1 days, respectively, for admissions with non-ICU encounters; 17.4 and 14.9 days for admissions with an ICU encounter; and 16.8 and 13.8 days for combined ICU/non-ICU admissions.
results.page_location: Page 4, Outcomes associated with CLABSI and non-CLABSI HOB in case-matched analyses by ICU status

results.statement: Impact of CAUTI. The mean incremental cost per patient for CAUTI is INR 1,55,963 over a year
results.reference: Chacko B, Thomas K, David T, Paul H, Jeyaseelan L, Peter JV. Attributable cost of a nosocomial infection in the intensive care unit: A prospective cohort study. World Journal of Critical Care Medicine. 2017;6(1):79.
results.matched_evidence: - 8. Chacko, 2017.pdf: The mean (SD) cost (INR) CAUTI 190059 (34096) | No HAI¹ (n = 420) 115058 (93754) | Cost difference 155963

results.statement: Impact of CAUTI. CAUTI is the most common secondary cause of bloodstream infection
results.reference: Rabi R, Enaya A, Dana Mufeed Jomaa, et al. Catheter-associated urinary tract infections in critical care: Understanding incidence, risk factors, and pathogenic causes in Palestine. PLoS ONE. 2024;19(8):e0309755-e0309755.
results.matched_evidence: - 9. Rabi, 2024.pdf: Catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTI) are the most common secondary cause of bloodstream infection.

results.statement: ICMR and NTG. ICMR and NTG highlight CAUTIs as a priority in antimicrobial resistance control and advocate evidence-based guidelines for infection prevention and urinary catheter management.
results.matched_evidence: - 11. NTG Guidelines.pdf: The National Treatment Guidelines for Antimicrobial Use in Infectious Diseases was released in 2016 by National Centre for Disease Control. Indian Council of Medical Research in 2017 published Treatment Guidelines for Antimicrobial Use in Common Syndromes and 2nd edition of the same was released in 2019.

results.statement: Contribution of CAUTIs to AMR. 88% of CAUTI isolates are multidrug-resistant
results.reference: Purandare B, Jha T, Khaparde M, Parkhe TS, Lavate R. Incidence Risk Factors and Drug Resistance Patterns of Bacterial Isolates in Patients with Catheter-associated Urinary Tract Infections. Indian Journal of Critical Care Medicine. 2025;29(4):338-344.
results.matched_evidence: - 12. Jha, 2025.pdf: Multidrug resistance was detected in 37 (88.1%) of the 82 isolates.
results.page_location: Page 4, under the section "Multidrug Resistance (MDR) Organisms of CAUTIs"

results.statement: Contribution of CAUTIs to AMR. >90% resistance for key antibiotics
results.reference: Purandare B, Jha T, Khaparde M, Parkhe TS, Lavate R. Incidence Risk Factors and Drug Resistance Patterns of Bacterial Isolates in Patients with Catheter-associated Urinary Tract Infections. Indian Journal of Critical Care Medicine. 2025;29(4):338-344.
results.matched_evidence: - 12. Jha, 2025.pdf: Resistance among urinary isolates was 94% for cefoperazone-sulbactam, 90% for ampicillin, 80% for cefepime, 86.44% for amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, 84% for aztreonam, 64.40% for cefuroxime, 64% for piperacillin-tazobactam, ceftriaxone, and ceftazidime, 62.71% for cefotaxime, and 61.01 for trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole regardless of the bacterial species.
results.page_location: Page 4, Antibiotic Susceptibility Profiles of Bacterial Organisms

results.statement: Introducing Bardex™ I.C. Foley Catheter. Bardex™ I.C. Foley Catheter
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: ™

results.statement: Evidence-Based Clinical Performance. Upto 69% reduction in CAUTI incidence compared to standard latex catheters.
results.matched_evidence:
- 14. Chung, 2017.pdf: The incidences of catheter-associated urinary tract infection per 1000 catheter-days were 6.4 and 9.4, respectively (P=0.095).|There was a 31% reduction in the incidence of catheter-associated urinary tract infection per 1000 catheter-days in the silver-coated group.|Subgroup analysis revealed that the protective effect of silver-coated catheter was more pronounced in long-term users as well as female patients with a respective 48% (P=0.027) and 42% (P=0.108) reduction in incidence of catheter-associated urinary tract infection.
- 15. Kai Larsen, 2021.pdf: The incidence of symptomatic CAUTI was reduced by 69% in the BIP Foley Catheter group compared to the control group (6.5 vs 20.8 CAUTI/1000 catheter days), with an incidence rate ratio of 0.31 (95% confidence interval: 0.21–0.46; p < 0.001).
results.page_location: Page 2, Abstract and Results sections | Page 1, Results and conclusions section

results.statement: Evidence-Based Clinical Performance. 35% reduction in CAUTI incidence compared to standard silicone catheters.
results.reference: Bonfill X, Rigau D, Jáuregui-Abrisqueta ML, et al. A randomized controlled trial to assess the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of urinary catheters with silver alloy coating in spinal cord injured patients: trial protocol. BMC Urology. 2013;13(1).17. Zhao M, Geng S, Zhang L, et al. Prevention of urinary tract infection using a silver alloy hydrogel-coated catheter in critically ill patients: A single-center prospective randomized controlled study. Journal of Intensive Medicine. 2023;4(1).
results.matched_evidence:
- 16. Bonfill, 2013.pdf: The sample size was calculated on
the assumption that 24% of patients will suffer from an
UTI related to urinary catheterization, and a relative reduc-
tion of 35% with the use of catheters with antiseptic silver
alloy coating, which is considered clinically relevant.

results.statement: Evidence-Based Clinical Performance. 60% lower bacterial colonization after 30 days to prevent biofilm formation compared to siliconized latex foley catheter.
results.matched_evidence: - 17. Zhao, 2024.pdf: Bacterial biofilms on SAH catheters have only been investigated in vitro to date, and SAH catheters were shown to reduce bacterial colonization in vitro by 60% after 30 days, compared with conventional catheters.
results.page_location: Page 6, Discussion section, paragraph discussing biofilms

results.statement: Prolonged dwell time enables less frequent catheter changes. Bardex™ I.C. Foley catheters offer a dwell time of up to 28 days.
results.reference: Bardex IC Foley Catheter IFU.
results.matched_evidence: - 18. Bardex IC IFU.pdf: Recommended indwelling time not to exceed 28 days.

results.statement: Prolonged dwell time enables less frequent catheter changes. Silver-coated catheters are retained longer without complications compared to conventional catheters. *
results.matched_evidence: - 14. Chung, 2017.pdf: The mean catheterisation time per person was the longest in patients using a silver-coated catheter (17.0 days) compared with those using a conventional (10.8 days) or both types of catheter (13.6 days) [P=0.01].

results.statement: Prolonged dwell time enables less frequent catheter changes. Bardex™ I.C. Foley catheters offer a dwell time of up to 28 days.
results.reference: Bardex IC Foley Catheter IFU.
results.matched_evidence: - 18. Bardex IC IFU.pdf: Recommended indwelling time not to exceed 28 days.

results.statement: Enhanced comfort and superior patient satisfaction. >10x lower friction compared to uncoated catheters.
results.reference: Gao S, Zeng W, Liu Z, et al. Dual-Function Hydrogel Coating on Silicone Urinary Catheters with Durable Antibacterial Property and Lubricity. Gels. 2025;11(2):128-128.
results.matched_evidence: - 19. Gao, 2025.pdf: The hydrophilic properties of PVP hydrogel coatings facilitate catheter insertion by greatly minimizing friction between the catheter and ureteral tissue.|This aspect is vital for the successful implantation of catheters in the human body and may contribute to improved patient comfort [35].|As illustrated in Figure 5, the friction coefficient of the dual-function hydrogel coating-coated silicone urinary catheters was dramatically reduced compared to that of the pristine silicone urinary catheters.|After performing as many as 60 tests, the friction coefficient of silicone urinary catheters coated with DF-1 remained below 0.025, demonstrating the excellent adhesion and lubricity of the hydrogel coatings.

results.statement: Enhanced comfort and superior patient satisfaction. Hydrogel-coated surface maintained a friction coefficient <0.025, remaining <0.050 even after 30 days of simulated use.
results.reference: Gao S, Zeng W, Liu Z, et al. Dual-Function Hydrogel Coating on Silicone Urinary Catheters with Durable Antibacterial Property and Lubricity. Gels. 2025;11(2):128-128.
results.matched_evidence: - 19. Gao, 2025.pdf: As illustrated in Figure 5, the friction coefficient of the dual-function hydrogel coating-coated silicone urinary catheters was dramatically reduced compared to that of the pristine silicone urinary catheters.|After performing as many as 60 tests, the friction coefficient of silicone urinary catheters coated with DF-1 remained below 0.025, demonstrating the excellent adhesion and lubricity of the hydrogel coatings.|To further verify the durability and lubricity of the coating, we soaked the DF-1 hydrogel coating-coated silicone urinary catheters (named DF-1-S) in artificial urine at 37 °C for 30 days to simulate their in vivo use, and then tested the friction coefficient.|The coated catheters, after 60 tests, still had a friction coefficient below 0.050, indicating good adhesion and lubricity of the hydrogel coatings.

results.statement: Lower antibiotic sensitivity leading to low antimicrobial resistance. 75% fewer resistant strains compared to standard latex catheters.
results.reference: Saini D, Tiwari DK, Arora N, et al. Efficacy of Silver Coated Foley’s Catheter in Comparison with Latex Foley’s Catheter for Prevention of Antimicrobial Resistance and Catheter Associated Urinary Tract Infections in Obstructive Urolithiasis of Male Buffalo Calves. Indian Journal of Animal Research. 2022;(Of).
results.matched_evidence: - 20. Tiwari, 2022.pdf: The findings of this study are in correlation with the Rupp et al. (2004) where they reported that there is 56% decrease in CAUTI'S (Catheter associated urinary tract infection) in silver alloys catheters.

results.statement: Substantial reduction in economic burden. Upto 40% lower treatment costs with effective infection prevention.
results.reference: Kelly T, Ai C, Jung M, Yu K. Catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTIs) and non-CAUTI hospital-onset urinary tract infections: Relative burden, cost, outcomes and related hospital-onset bacteremia and fungemia infections. Infection Control and Hospital Epidemiology. 2024;45(7):1-8.
results.matched_evidence: - 21. Kelly, 2024.pdf: The overall total adjusted hospital costs for CAUTI patients and their controls were $24,289 (95% CI: $19,861-$29,703) and $14,482 (95% CI: $12,488-$16.794), respectively, yielding an average incremental cost of $9,807 (P < .0001).|For non-CAUTI HOUTIs and their controls, the overall total adjusted hospital costs were $21,363 (95% CI: $18,124-$25,180) and $14,489 (95% CI: $12,422-$16,899), respectively, yielding an average incremental cost of $6,874 (P < .0001) (Table 2).
results.page_location: Page 4, Attributable cost of CAUTI and non-CAUTI HOUTI

results.statement: Urological Association of Asia & Asian Association of Urinary Tract Infection & STIs. Recommends hydrophilic-coated or antibiotic/silver alloy coated catheters to reduce CAUTIs and asymptomatic bacteriuria, especially in settings with high resistance burden.
results.reference: Chuang L, Tambyah PA. Catheter-associated urinary tract infection. Journal of Infection and Chemotherapy. 2021;27(10). doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jiac.2021.07.022
results.matched_evidence:
- 22. Urological Association of Asia Guidelines.pdf: Evidence for antibiotic or antiseptic impregnated or coated urinary
catheters are as follows [22,40-43]:|• Use of hydrophilic-coated catheters was associated with a lower
incidence of CAUTIs [41,42,44].|• Silver alloy catheters significantly reduced incidence of
asymptomatic bacteriuria, and may be considered.

results.statement: International Society for Infectious Diseases (ISID). Recommends the use of silver alloy hydrogel-coated (SAH) Foley catheters as an effective measure to reduce CAUTIs.
results.reference: Rosenthal V, Memish Z, Nicastri E, Leone S, Bearman G. GUIDE to INFECTION CONTROL in the HEALTHCARE SETTING Recommendations for the Prevention of Catheter-Associated Urinary Tract Infections Chapter Editor Topic Outline. https://isid.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/ISID_GUIDE_CHAPTER_CAUTI.pdf
results.matched_evidence: - 23. ISID Guidelines.pdf: In their study titled "Prevention of urinary tract infection using a silver alloy hydrogel-coated catheter in critically ill patients: A single-center prospective randomized controlled study," Zhao et al. (2024) examined the efficacy of a silver alloy hydrogel-coated (SAH) catheter +in preventing CAUTI among 132 critically ill ICU patients.
results.page_location: Page 10, under the heading "Use of silver alloy hydrogel-coated (SAH) catheter."

results.statement: HPSC Ireland (Health Protection Surveillance Centre). Suggests considering antiseptic or antimicrobial-coated catheters if local CAUTI rates persist despite implementation of multiple prevention strategies.
results.reference: Guidelines for the Prevention of Catheterassociated Urinary Tract Infection Published on behalf of SARI by HSE Health Protection Surveillance Centre 2011. Accessed on https://www.hpsc.ie/a-z/microbiologyantimicrobialresistance/infectioncontrolandhai/guidelines/File,12913,en.pdf
results.matched_evidence: - 24. HPSC Ireland guidelines.pdf: Consider the use of antiseptic or antimicrobial-coated catheters if the local CAUTI rate is not decreasing despite implementation of a multi-system approach: including optimisation of aseptic technique, appropriate management of catheters and regular audit and feedback of surveillance data.
results.page_location: Page 7, Section 1, Summary of Recommendations, F. Type of catheter

results.statement: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). If CAUTI rate does not fall after implementing comprehensive prevention strategies, antimicrobial/ antiseptic coated catheters may be considered.
results.reference: Gould C, Umscheid C, Rajender, Agarwal K, Kuntz G, Pegues D. Guideline for Prevention of Catheter-Associated Urinary Tract Infections 2009.; 2019. https://www.cdc.gov/infection-control/media/pdfs/Guideline-CAUTI-H.pdf
results.matched_evidence: - 25. CDC Guidelines.pdf: If the CAUTI rate is not decreasing after implementing a comprehensive strategy to reduce rates of CAUTI, consider using antimicrobial/antiseptic-impregnated catheters.
results.page_location: Page 14, Section Catheter Materials, Paragraph M

results.statement: Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA). For short-term indwelling urethral catheterization, antimicrobial-coated catheters (silver alloy or antibiotic) may be considered to reduce or delay CA-bacteriuria.
results.reference: Hooton TM, Bradley SF, Cardenas DD, et al. Diagnosis, Prevention, and Treatment of Catheter-Associated Urinary Tract Infection in Adults: 2009 International Clinical Practice Guidelines from the Infectious Diseases Society of America. Clinical Infectious Diseases. 2010;50(5):625-663. Abbreviations: CAUTI: Catheter associated urinary tract infections; CDC: Centers for disease control and prevention; ICU: Intensive care unit; INR: Indian rupee; ICMR: Indian council of medical research; NTG: National treatment guidelines; AMR: Antimicrobial resistance; IC: Infection control.
results.matched_evidence: - 26. IDSA Guidelines.pdf: In patients with short-term indwelling urethral cathe- terization, antimicrobial (silver alloy or antibiotic)-coated uri- nary catheters may be considered to reduce or delay the onset of CA-bacteriuria (B-II).
